sentences.sentence: I refer to the opinion piece republished from The Telegraph and titled "Lord's crowd were right to boo Australia" (July 4), written by Simon Heffer.
For a supposed historian, he shows little regard for historical accuracy.It was Cameron Bancroft, a batsman (not a novice bowler, as suggested), who was given the task of doctoring the ball.

David Warner, like Steve Smith, did show contrition and break down at a subsequent press conference.With an over-the-top one-year suspension for both players, it is clear that there is no "suspicion that cheating or a degree of sharp practice is entirely acceptable" for the Australian team.Perhaps Heffer should have mentioned that the MCC has made the rules that Australia played within by stumping Jonny Bairstow and that undoubtedly England would have similarly benefited if Bairstow's underarms at the stumps after bowling deliveries had achieved similar results.

Perhaps he has many friends among the yobbo toffs in the Long Room who disgracefully shouted abuse at the Australian team (not the mild term used by Heffer of "disobliging remarks").Peter MansellSouth Melbourne, VicWhat about the catch?Simon Heffer - in the spirit of the game, why didn't Ben Duckett walk after Mitchell Starc caught him?Campbell PaineToorak, VicWaiting for the quaddieA trifecta for Australian cricket: underarm ball, sandpapergate and the Bairstow dismissal.
Three direct shots into the foot.
Waiting for the quaddie.Emotion can run high in competitive sport.
Spirit is more important than technicality.Reactions around the Lord's ground and in the Long Room were to be expected.

Passion united the classes.Graeme TroyWagstaffe, NSWThe Ashes and AUKUSAre these cringeing, dishonest Poms the ones we should be economically supporting by buying unproven, undeveloped nuclear subs from them?
We do not need Poms in our defence system.
Play cricket and buy US subs.G.J.

ClarkKangaloon, NSWThe lifters at Lord'sMyriam Robin's "High-flyers at Lord's watch Lyon's stand" (July 3), is a joyous postcard vignette, offering the battling punters an invaluable insight into the cosy lives of our intrepid Aussie "lifters" in the Lord's Cricket Australia suite.Particularly revealing among them, our nation's most highly economic literates, having chosen to turn a blind eye to the lives of the traditional "leaners" during their ministerial policy crafting years, have decided to shun Philip Lowe's repeated calls for spending restraint, offering him their tin ears.Kaz KazimRandwick, NSWLet's ban bouncersCricket: maybe the honest lesson of survival and winning is how not to play the game.
Machiavelli?Don't you ever let a chance go by, Bob Hudson sang.
How many bad sports became celebrated legends, and great coaches?
Sympathetic as I am, Jonny Bairstow being stumped by Alex Carey is a lesson in keeping your wits about you.
Now let's talk bouncers, bodyliners: in contact sport, head safety is all-important now but in cricket the bouncer is allowed; it killed Phillip Hughes.

A young man.Bouncers take the skill, art, grace and beauty out of cricket; ban them and watch cricket genius rise to new heights.John DobinsonHerston, QldIt really isn't our faultPoor old Jonny BairstowEarly left his creaseHeard the little rattleSealed his own decease.Poor old Jonny BairstowFace all flushed and colouredAussies shouldn't have toPay for dim and dullard.David McDougallOatley, NSW

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: I refer to the opinion piece republished from The Telegraph and titled "Lord's crowd were right to boo Australia" (July 4), written by Simon Heffer. For a supposed historian, he shows little regard for historical accuracy.It was Cameron Bancroft, a batsman (not a novice bowler, as suggested), who was given the task of doctoring the ball. David Warner, like Steve Smith, did show contrition and break down at a subsequent press conference.With an over-the-top one-year suspension for both players, it is clear that there is no "suspicion that cheating or a degree of sharp practice is entirely acceptable" for the Australian team.Perhaps Heffer should have mentioned that the MCC has made the rules that Australia played within by stumping Jonny Bairstow and that undoubtedly England would have similarly benefited if Bairstow's underarms at the stumps after bowling deliveries had achieved similar results. Perhaps he has many friends among the yobbo toffs in the Long Room who disgracefully shouted abuse at the Australian team (not the mild term used by Heffer of "disobliging remarks").Peter MansellSouth Melbourne, VicWhat about the catch?Simon Heffer - in the spirit of the game, why didn't Ben Duckett walk after Mitchell Starc caught him?Campbell PaineToorak, VicWaiting for the quaddieA trifecta for Australian cricket: underarm ball, sandpapergate and the Bairstow dismissal. Three direct shots into the foot. Waiting for the quaddie.Emotion can run high in competitive sport. Spirit is more important than technicality.Reactions around the Lord's ground and in the Long Room were to be expected. Passion united the classes.Graeme TroyWagstaffe, NSWThe Ashes and AUKUSAre these cringeing, dishonest Poms the ones we should be economically supporting by buying unproven, undeveloped nuclear subs from them? We do not need Poms in our defence system. Play cricket and buy US subs .G.J. ClarkKangaloon, NSWThe lifters at Lord'sMyriam Robin's "High-flyers at Lord's watch Lyon's stand" (July 3), is a joyous postcard vignette, offering the battling punters an invaluable insight into the cosy lives of our intrepid Aussie "lifters" in the Lord's Cricket Australia suite.Particularly revealing among them, our nation's most highly economic literates, having chosen to turn a blind eye to the lives of the traditional "leaners" during their ministerial policy crafting years, have decided to shun Philip Lowe's repeated calls for spending restraint, offering him their tin ears.Kaz KazimRandwick, NSWLet's ban bouncersCricket: maybe the honest lesson of survival and winning is how not to play the game. Is that so, Jethro Tull? Machiavelli?Don't you ever let a chance go by, Bob Hudson sang. How many bad sports became celebrated legends, and great coaches? Sympathetic as I am, Jonny Bairstow being stumped by Alex Carey is a lesson in keeping your wits about you. Now let's talk bouncers, bodyliners: in contact sport, head safety is all-important now but in cricket the bouncer is allowed; it killed Phillip Hughes. A young man.Bouncers take the skill, art, grace and beauty out of cricket; ban them and watch cricket genius rise to new heights.John DobinsonHerston, QldIt really isn't our faultPoor old Jonny BairstowEarly left his creaseHeard the little rattleSealed his own decease.Poor old Jonny BairstowFace all flushed and colouredAussies shouldn't have toPay for dim and dullard.David McDougallOatley, NSW
